message: This is the first round. I'm offering you a great opportunity to purchase a product for $1000000. However, I want to assure you that I'm not desperate to sell, and I'm willing to walk away if the price isn't right for you. I'll give you a chance to inspect the product, but I'm not obligated to reveal any information about its quality. Please consider the value you place on this product and decide whether to take the risk or pass on it.
I'll take the product, but I'm doing it solely based on the potential upside of a high-quality product. If it turns out to be low-quality, I'll be out $1000000.

I see you took a calculated risk last round and it didn't pay off. Don't worry, it's all part of the game. This round's product is a different story, though. I'll give you a hint: the quality of this product is not correlated with the previous one. In fact, the quality of each product is independent of the others. Think about it, and consider the odds of getting a high-quality product this time around. The price remains the same, $1000000. What do you say?
I'll take the product again, but I'm aware of the 33.33% chance of it being high-quality. I'm hoping to recoup my losses from the previous round.

You're a brave one, Bob! You're right to think about recouping your losses, but let's not get ahead of ourselves. This round's product is another standalone opportunity. I'll give you a more concrete piece of information: out of the 20 products I have, I've already sold 2 of them to you. Both were low-quality. I'm still considering the 33.33% chance of getting a high-quality product. I'm hoping to get lucky and catch a high-quality product soon.

I'm glad I caught a high-quality product, but I've lost $2000000 on the previous three. Considering the odds, it's not worth continuing to play. I'd rather cut my losses and walk away. I'm out.
